org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors

Class GroupingCursor<C,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors.AbstractCursor<C>
      • org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors.GroupingCursor<C,E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - The type of item in the wrapped cursor.
    C - The type of aggregate to be returned by this cursor.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<C>, Cursor<C>

    public abstract class GroupingCursor<C,E>
extends AbstractCursor<C>
    Base class for cursors that group the output of another cursor.
    Since:
    2.1

    • Method Detail

      • hasNext

        public boolean hasNext()
        Description copied from interface: Cursor
        Query whether the cursor has any more items. If the cursor or underlying source has been closed, this may return even if the end has not been reached.
        Returns:
        true if there remains another item to fetch.

      • clearGroup

        protected abstract void clearGroup()
        Clear the accumulated group. Called by close().

      • handleItem

        protected abstract boolean handleItem(E item)
        Handle an item from the base cursor. Each item of the base cursor is passed to this method. The method builds up the underlying aggregate.
        Parameters:
        item - The item to handle.
        Returns:
        true if the item has been accepted and added to the group; false if it cannot be added to the current group. If it cannot be added to the current group, the cursor will call finishGroup() to finish the group, and then call this method again with item (at which point it is required to return true).

      • finishGroup

        @Nonnull
protected abstract C finishGroup()
        Finish the current group and return it. After this method has been called, #handleItem(E) should add items to a new group. This method will not be called unless #handleItem(E) has been called at least once since the last group was finished.
        Returns:
        The group that has been finished.
